text:
{{Infobox company | name = Mobileye | logo = [[Image:mobileye logo.jpg|250px]] | logo_size = | logo_padding = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = Ambassador's visit to Mobileye (24738214069).jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = U.S. Ambassador visiting Mobileye at [[Har Hotzvim]] Technology park | trading_name = | native_name = | type = [[Subsidiary]] of [[Intel]] | traded_as = | ISIN = | industry = [[Automotive]] [[Autonomous Cars]] | founded = {{start date and age|1999}}
[[Jerusalem]] | founder = Ziv Aviram
[[Amnon Shashua]] | hq_location = | hq_location_city = | hq_location_country = Israel | num_locations = | num_locations_year = | area_served = | key_people = Amnon Shashua
(CEO, CTO and Vice President at Intel) | products = | brands =EyeQ chip | production = | production_year = | services = | revenue = [[United States dollar|USD]] 358.16 million | revenue_year = 2016 | operating_income = [[United States dollar|USD]] 120.94 million | income_year = 2016 | net_income = [[United States dollar|USD]] 108.37 million | net_income_year = 2016 | assets = [[United States dollar|USD]] 780.38 million | assets_year = 2016 | equity = [[United States dollar|USD]] 698.41 million | equity_year = 2016 | owner = | num_employees = 750 | num_employees_year = 2017 | parent = [[Intel]] | divisions = | subsid = | module = | website = http://www.mobileye.com/ | footnotes = | slogan = Sensing the Future }} '''Mobileye''' is an [[Israel]]i technology company that develops vision-based [[advanced driver-assistance systems]] (ADAS) providing warnings for [[traffic collision|collision]] prevention and mitigation. Mobileye N.V. headquarters and main R&D centre is located in [[Jerusalem]] operating under the company name Mobileye Vision Technology Ltd.{{cite web|url=https://www.israelbizreg.com/mobileye-vision-technologies-ltd|title=MOBILEYE VISION TECHNOLOGIES LTD {{!}} Israel Company Reports – Search Israeli Companies|website=www.israelbizreg.com|access-date=2016-10-06}} The company has also sales and marketing offices in [[Jericho, New York]]; [[Shanghai, China]]; [[Tokyo|Tokyo, Japan]] and [[Düsseldorf|Düsseldorf, Germany]]. In March 2017, [[Intel]] announced that they had agreed to a US$15.3 billion takeover of Mobileye.{{cite news|title=Intel buys driverless car technology firm Mobileye|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-39253422|accessdate=13 March 2017|work=BBC|date=13 March 2017}} The deal is expected to be the largest exit in Israel's high-tech industry to date.{{cite web|author=מובילאיי |url=http://www.themarker.com/markets/1.3921460 |title=אינטל מאשרת את חשיפת TheMarker: תרכוש את מובילאיי ב-15.3 מיליארד דולר – שוק ההון |publisher=TheMarker |date=2017-03-13 |accessdate=2017-03-18}} [[File:Lane Guidance Camera PCB.jpg|thumb|right|A MobileEye EyeQ2 chip used in a Hyundai Lane Guidance camera module.]] ==History== Mobileye N.V. was founded in 1999 by [[Amnon Shashua]] (a researcher of the [[Hebrew University]]), when he evolved his academic research into a technical solution for a vision system which could detect vehicles using only a camera and software [[algorithms]] on a processor.[https://web.archive.org/web/20160204085223/http://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=543997&privcapId=24494124] After receiving a license to use the technology which was owned by [[Yissum Research Development Company of the Hebrew University|Yissum]] it was possible to incorporate the company. Together with Ziv Aviram, he set up the company's [[R&D]] headquarters in Jerusalem, Israel. At first, the company developed algorithms, and a [[AI accelerator (computer hardware)|custom accelerator processor chip]] called the ''EyeQ'' chip. All of Mobileye’s proprietary image processing algorithms run on the EyeQ chip. After years of testing, the chip and software algorithms began to be sold as commercial products to [[original equipment manufacturer]] (OEM) customers. The company’s first clients were [[automotive industry|automotive manufacturers]] such as BMW, General Motors and Volvo. These companies electronics suppliers integrated Mobileye’s technologies into the companies' cars, at first as an optional accessory when buying a new car, and later as a standard option in new cars.{{cite web|last=Sarah |first=Viva |url=http://www.israel21c.org/what-drives-israels-serial-entrepreneurs/ |title=What drives Israel’s serial entrepreneurs? |publisher=ISRAEL21c |date=2014-03-23 |accessdate=2017-03-18}} In 2006, Mobileye set up an aftermarket department, which sells finished products manufactured by Mobileye at their [[Philippines]] factory, IMI. The [[Aftermarket (automotive)|aftermarket]] products are sold to an international network of distributors on all continents who sell the products to fleets of trucks and buses, to car dealerships, and to car accessory shops.[http://www.timesofisrael.com/nyc-taxis-to-be-a-little-safer-thanks-to-mobileye/ NYC taxis to be a little safer, thanks to Mobileye: Israeli road safety alert system is being installed in New York cabs to help their operators drive more safely], David Shamah, Times of Israel 15 June 2015 In August 2015, [[Tesla Motors]] announced that it is using Mobileye's technology to enable its self-drive solution, which would be incorporated into Model S cars from August 2015.[http://news.nocamels.com/2015/08/23/mobileyes-tech-powers-tesla-model-s/ Mobileye’s Tech Powers Tesla Model] NoCamels News 23 August 2015 After the first deadly crash of a self-driving [[Tesla Model S|Model S]] with active ''Autopilot'' became public in June 2016, Mobileye issued a statement that its technology won't be able to recognize a crossing trailer (which was the cause of the accident) until 2018.[https://www.theverge.com/2016/7/1/12085218/tesla-autopilot-crash-investigation-radar-automatic-emergency-braking Tesla and Mobileye disagree on lack of emergency braking in deadly Autopilot crash], on [[The Verge]], July 1, 2016 In July 2016, Mobileye announced the end of its partnership with Tesla after the EyeQ3.{{cite news|last1=Bhuiyan|first1=Johana|title=In the wake of a fatal crash, Tesla will quit using Mobileye's chips for Autopilot vision|url=http://www.recode.net/2016/7/26/12285930/tesla-mobileye-self-driving-cars|accessdate=26 July 2016|publisher=ReCode|date=26 July 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Korosec|first1=Kristen|title=Mobileye Is Ending Its Relationship With Tesla on Future Self-Driving Car Tech|url=http://fortune.com/2016/07/26/mobileye-tesla-self-driving-cars/|accessdate=26 July 2016|publisher=Fortune|date=26 July 2016}} EyeQ is used in over 15 million vehicles sold as of 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/news/business/21718941-israeli-firm-and-tech-giant-team-up-shape-future-cars-mobileye-and-intel-join|title=Mobileye and Intel join forces|website=The Economist|access-date=2017-04-01}} In January 2017, Mobileye, [[BMW]] and [[Intel]] announced that they were developing a test fleet of autonomous vehicles that would be on the road in the second half of 2017.{{cite web|url=http://s2.q4cdn.com/670976801/files/doc_news/2017-BMW-Intel-Mobileye-release_CES.pdf|title=BMW Group, Intel and Mobileye will have autonomous test vehicles on the roads by the second half of 2017|last=|first=|date=4 January 2017|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} The companies plan to develop autonomous vehicles for the consumer market by 2021.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alanohnsman/2017/01/13/mobileye-wants-to-teach-your-robotic-car-to-merge-in-heavy-boston-traffic/#3ad58c1b33a9|title=Mobileye Wants To Teach Your Robotic Car To Merge In Heavy Boston Traffic|last=Ohnsman|first=Alan|newspaper=Forbes|access-date=2017-01-13}} In March 2017, Intel announced their recent deals to buy Mobileye for $15.3 billion.{{Cite news|url=http://www.investopedia.com/news/intel-buys-mobileye-153b-intc-mbly/?partner=YahooSA&yptr=yahoo|title=Intel Buys Mobileye for $15.3B|last=Sharma|first=Rakesh|date=2017-03-13|work=Investopedia|access-date=2017-03-13|language=en-US}} The deal was completed August 8. ==Company timeline== *1999: Mobileye NV co-founded by Mr. Ziv Aviram and Prof. [[Amnon Shashua]]{{cite web|url=http://www.linkedin.com/companies/24017?trk=ape_s000001e_1000 |title=Mobileye's LinkedIn Profile |publisher=Linkedin.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-13}} *1999 (June): Introduction of the first generation Live Demonstration System *1999: Mobileye received a license from [[Yissum Research Development Company of the Hebrew University|Yissum]] to be able to use the technology. *2000: Introduction of the second generation Live Demonstration System *2001 (February): Introduction of the third generation Live Demonstration System *2001 (May): Introduction of the fourth generation Live Demonstration System *2002: Introduction of the fifth generation Live Demonstration System for Multi-Vision Applications *2003: Mobileye and [[Denso]] sign cooperation agreement *2003: Mobileye and [[Delphi Corporation|Delphi]] sign cooperation agreement *2004: Introduction of the first generation EyeQ [[System-on-a-Chip]] (SoC) *2004: Mobileye and SVDO/Continental sign a development agreement *2005: Mobileye and [[ST Microelectronics|ST Microelectrionics]] sign a chip manufacture and development partnership agreement[http://www.st.com/stonline/press/news/year2005/t1718a.htm View ST Microelectronics Press Release] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070922060718/http://www.st.com/stonline/press/news/year2005/t1718a.htm |date=September 22, 2007 }} *2006: Introduction of the sixth generation Live Demonstration System for Pedestrian Detection *2006: Introduction of Mobileye's Aftermarket Department *2006 (July): Mobileye and [[Magna International|Magna Electronics]] announce partnership to develop advanced automotive driver assistance features[http://www.magna.com/magna/en/media/pressreleases/default.aspx?i=171 ]{{dead link|date=March 2017}} *2007: U.S. investment bank [[Goldman Sachs]] invests $100 million in Mobileye{{cite web|last=Gabay |first=Eran |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/912422.html |title=Goldman Sachs investing $100m in startup Mobileye |publisher=Haaretz.com |date=2008-04-02 |accessdate=2011-11-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080917092326/http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/912422.html |archivedate=2008-09-17 |df= }} *2007: Mobileye launches multiple series productions for LDW on GM [[Cadillac STS]] and DTS vehicles,{{cite web|url=http://www.newswiretoday.com/news/28511/ |title=View PRNewswire Press Release |publisher=Newswiretoday.com |date=2008-01-15 |accessdate=2011-11-13}} for LDW on [[BMW 5]] and 6 Series vehicles[http://www.usa.vdo.com/generator/www/us/en/vdo/main/press/releases/chassis_and_carbody/2007/sv_20070416_b_en.html]{{dead link|date=November 2011}} and for radar-vision fusion for enhanced [[Adaptive Cruise Control]] with Collision Mitigation by Braking on Volvo S80, XC90/70/60 and V70 vehicles[http://www.mobileye.com/sites/mobileye.com/files/Volvo.AutoBrake_0.pdf ]{{dead link|date=March 2017}} *2007: Introduction of the Mobileye Advanced Warning System providing a world's first Aftermarket system featuring functions of lane and vehicle Detection running on a single processor{{cite web|url=http://www.newswiretoday.com/news/31703/ |title=View News Wire Today |publisher=Newswiretoday.com |date=2008-03-24 |accessdate=2011-11-13}} *2008 (September): Mobileye and Continental launch a world's first combination of multiple functions of Lane Departure Warning, Intelligent Highbeam Control and Traffic Sign Recognition on the BMW 7 series{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-184582216.html |title=View High Beam News Article |publisher=Highbeam.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-13}} *2008: Introduction of the second generation EyeQ2 System-on-a-Chip (SoC)[http://www.st.com/stonline/stappl/cms/press/news/year2008/t2283.htm View STMicroelectronics Press Release] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081023070618/http://www.st.com/stonline/stappl/cms/press/news/year2008/t2283.htm |date=October 23, 2008 }} *2009: Mobileye and [[Visteon]] sign cooperation agreement [http://www.tradingmarkets.com/.site/news/Stock%20News/2357532]{{dead link|date=November 2011}} *2010: Co-Founders Ziv Aviram and Amnon Shashua launch the company [http://www.orcam.com/ OrCam] *2010: U.S. investment bank [[Goldman Sachs]], [[Bank Leumi|Leumi Partners]] and Menora Mivtachim Holdings Ltd. invest $37 million in Mobileye[http://www.tradingmarkets.com/news/stock-alert/gs_mnrhf_car-safety-co-mobileye-raises-37m-investors-include-goldman-sachs-leumi-partners-and-menorah-miv-850325.html]{{dead link|date=November 2011}} *2010: Mobileye launches newest aftermarket product, the C2-270 Collision Prevention System, with vehicle, pedestrian, bicycle, and motorcycle detection capabilities.[https://web.archive.org/web/20110714110053/http://www.mobileye.com/en/press-room/press-releases] * 2010: Mobileye launches a world-first vision based Pedestrian Forward Collision Warning as part of a radar-vision 'automatic emergency braking system' with Delphi and [[Volvo cars|Volvo]] on the [[Volvo S60|S60]] saloon and [[Volvo V60|V60]] estate * 2010: Mobileye launches Lane Keeping and Support (LKAS) on two HKMC vehicles ([[Hyundai i40]] and [[Kia Optima]]) for US and European introduction. * 2011: Mobileye launches the world's first vision only based forward collision warning system (bundled with multiple other functions of LDW IHC and TSR) on the 2011 BMW 1 series * 2011: Mobileye launches the world's first vision only based U.S. [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]] (NHTSA) compliant Forward Collision Warning system and lane departure warning system combination on multiple GM vehicles – [[Chevrolet Equinox]] and [[GMC Terrain]]. * 2011: Mobileye launches multi functional bundles including vision based FCW on the [[Opel Zafira]] and [[Opel Insignia]]. * 2014: Mobileye launched its IPO on the NYSE which was the biggest Israeli IPO ever in the US raising approx. $1B at a market cap of $5.3B{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-07-31/mobileye-raises-890-million-as-largest-israeli-ipo-in-the-u-s-.html | work=Bloomberg | first=Gabrielle | last=Coppola | title=Mobileye Raises $890 Million as Largest Israeli IPO in the U.S | date=2014-07-31}} * 2017: Acquired by Intel for $15.3B {{cite web|url=http://intelandmobileye.transactionannouncement.com/ |title=Intel acquisition of Mobileye |website=Intelandmobileye.transactionannouncement.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-18}} ==Technologies== The firm's technology is based on the use of optical vision systems with motion detection algorithms running on a custom hardware accelerator - the '''EyeQ''' chip. This is unlike many other competing systems which use a combination of visual detection, radar, and laser scanning. The firm's vehicle detection algorithms recognize motorised vehicles such as cars, motorcycles and trucks, in day and night time conditions.{{Citation needed|date=January 2015}} The firm's version performs its vehicle detection based functions using a single camera mounted in the rear view mirror, unlike the usual approach of using radars, laser scanners or in some cases stereo-cameras.{{cite web|url=http://consumerreports.org/cro/magazine/2013/11/safety-upgrades-for-your-car/index.htm |title=Mobileye 560 Review | Goshers Blind Spot Detection System |publisher=Consumer Reports |date= |accessdate=2017-03-18}} In 2011 the firm introduced the world's first OEM production of vision-only [[Precrash system|forward collision warning system]] (NHTSA compliant) on multiple BMW, GM and Opel vehicles.{{Citation needed|date=January 2015}} [[Lane departure warning system]]s are in-vehicle electronic systems that monitor the position of a vehicle within a roadway lane and warn a driver if the vehicle deviates or is about to deviate outside the lane. Mobileye's version was launched in multiple production platforms through 2007 and 2008 with [[General Motors|GM]], [[BMW]] and [[Volvo]]. {{citation needed |date=January 2013}} The firm's [[pedestrian detection]] technology is based on the use of mono cameras only, using pattern recognition and classifiers with image processing and optic flow analysis. Both static and moving pedestrians can be detected to a range of around 30m using [[VGA]] resolution imagers.{{Citation needed|date=January 2015}} The firm announced in 2008 that by mid-2010 they would launch a world's first application of full emergency braking for collision mitigation for pedestrians. Mobileye announced in May 2009 as part of the next generation Volvo radar-vision fusion system which also provides lane departure warning and vehicle detection with radar-vision fusion for an enhanced collision mitigation by braking system on the next [[Volvo S60]] vehicle.{{cite web|last=Administrator |first=Cars |url=http://carszainfo.blogspot.com/2009/10/volvo-cars-tests-new-unique-safety.html |title=Cars.co.za: Volvo Cars tests new, unique safety technology in Copenhagen – in a disguised S60 prototype |publisher=Carszainfo.blogspot.com |date=2009-10-14 |accessdate=2011-11-13}}{{unreliable source?|date=January 2014}} Since 2008, BMW 7-Series cars are equipped with the Mobileye [[traffic sign recognition]] systems, developed in cooperation with automotive supplier [[Continental AG]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20110604100132/http://www.motortrend.com/features/newswire/38117/index.html ] Adaptive [[High beam|highbeam]] systems automatically raises and lowering the high beams without inconveniencing oncoming or preceding traffic. The firm's version, Intelligent Headlight Control, is in production on the [[BMW 7 Series (F01)|BMW 7 series]].{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.autospies.com/news/BMW-7-Series-and-its-amazing-Headlights-System-38669 |title=BMW 7 Series and its amazing Headlights System - AutoSpies Auto News |website=Autospies.com |date=2008-12-10 |accessdate=2017-03-18}} In 2011, the firm introduced multi-functional bundles including vision based FCW on the [[Opel Zafira]] and [[Opel Insignia]]. In 2016, Mobileye announced a deal to work with [[Renault|Renault Nissan]] on digital maps that will help the automaker’s move towards driverless cars.{{Cite news|title = Mobileye takes fight to Google in autonomous cars|url = http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/21dbe238-da3a-11e5-a72f-1e7744c66818.html#axzz416qWYkRE|newspaper = Financial Times|date = 2016-02-24|access-date = 2016-02-24|issn = 0307-1766|first = John|last = Reed|first2 = Murad|last2 = Ahmed}} ===Aftermarket=== Since 2007 the firm has offered a range of aftermarket vision based ADAS systems, based on the same core technology as for production models. They currently offer lane departure warning, forward collision warning, headway monitoring and warning, low speed urban collision warning, intelligent headlamp control, speed limit indication (tsr) and pedestrian collision warning (including bicycles). These systems have also been integrated with fleet management systems.{{cite web|url = http://fleetowner.com/equipment/news/installernet-mobileye-installation-0414|title = InstallerNet to handle installation of Mobileye systems|date = Apr 14, 2010|accessdate = 2015-01-26|website = Fleet Owner|publisher = Fleet Owner|last = |first = }} ==Investments== Between 2007 and 2011 the company raised $160 million. In 2013 the company sold 25% of its private shares for $400 million to a group of blue-chip investors.{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/business/.premium-1.591207|title=Crash-avoidance Car Firm Mobileye Reportedly Eyes Monster $1b IPO|first1=Michael|last1=Rochvarger|first2=Daniel|last2=Schmil|date=17 May 2014|publisher=|via=Haaretz}}{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/business/.premium-1.534607|title=Israeli Startup Mobileye Selling 25% Stake for $400m to Group of Blue-chip Investors|first1=Michael|last1=Rochvarger|first2=Daniel|last2=Schmil|date=8 July 2013|publisher=Haaretz}}{{cite web|last=Lloyd |first=William |url=https://www.wsj.com/europe/ |title=The Wall Street Journal & Breaking News, Business, Financial and Economic News, World News and Video |website=Wsj.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-18}} One of Mobileye's biggest investors was [[Colmobil]] CEO Shmuel Harlap, who held a 7.2% stake.{{cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-the-mobileye-winners-1001180719|title=The Mobileye billionaires – Globes English|author=|date=|work=globes.co.il|accessdate=18 March 2017}} Following the acquisition, he'll become Israel's newest billionaire, joining co-founders [[Amnon Shashua]] and [[Ziv Aviram]] in the billionaire's club.{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/angelauyeung/2017/03/13/intels-15-3-b-bid-for-mobileye-pushes-israeli-investor-into-the-billionaire-ranks/#4a607c6c58cb |title=Intel's $15.3 Billion Bid For Mobileye Pushes Israeli Investor Into The Billionaire Ranks |website=Forbes.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-18}} ==Awards== * International Fleet Industry Award, Fleet Europe, November 2013 {{cite web|url=http://www.fleeteurope.com/news/international-fleet-industry-award-2013-mobileye-awarded-again |title=News |publisher=Fleet Europe |date=2016-12-14 |accessdate=2017-03-18}} * International Fleet Industry Award, Fleet Europe, October 2011.[https://web.archive.org/web/20120222235853/http://www.fleeteurope.com/mobileye_wins_the_international_fleet_industry_award_2011_51708-en-146-181920.html ] * Fleet Safety Forum Award for Excellence in the UK, for the Fleet Safety Product category, for the Mobileye C2-170 safety system.[http://www.brake.org.uk/events/awards-for-excellence Fleet Safety Forum Award Winners ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091220043422/http://www.brake.org.uk/events/awards-for-excellence |date=December 20, 2009 }} [[Brake (charity)|Brake – Road Safety Charity -]], July 2009. * Best Electronic Design 2008 for Best Automotive Design, for the EyeQ2 Vision Processor.{{cite web|url=http://electronicdesign.com/Articles/Index.cfm?AD=1&ArticleID=20261&bypass=1 |title=2008 Winner's List |publisher=Electronicdesign.com |date=2008-12-04 |accessdate=2011-11-13}} ''[[Electronic Design (magazine)|Electronic Design]]'', December 2008. * Entrepreneurial Company of the Year Award in the Automotive Industry. Frost & Sullivan, December 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.frost.com/prod/servlet/press-release.pag?mode=open&docid=89716687 |title=Frost & Sullivan Press Release |publisher=Frost.com |date=2006-12-14 |accessdate=2011-11-13}} * Selected for the Top 100 Innovators Award. [[Red Herring (magazine)|Red Herring Magazine]], December 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/automotive/automotive-overview/5603515-1.html |title=View Press Release |publisher=Allbusiness.com |date=2004-12-09 |accessdate=2011-11-13}} == Chips == === Comparison === {| class="wikitable" |+ !Mobileye{{Cite news|url=https://www.mobileye.com/our-technology/evolution-eyeq-chip/|title=The Evolution of EyeQ - Mobileye|work=Mobileye|access-date=2017-12-08|language=en-US}} !EyeQ1 !EyeQ2 !EyeQ3 !EyeQ4 !EyeQ5 |- |On market |2008 |2010 |2014 |2018 |2020 |- |Claimed autonomous level | colspan="2" |Driver Assistance |2 |3 |4-5 |- |Performance (FP16 TFLOPS) |0,0044 |0,026 |0,256 |2,5 |24 |- |Power consumption |2,5 watt |2,5 watt |2,5 watt |3 watt |10 watt |- |Semiconductor node |180nm CMOS |90nm CMOS |40nm CMOS |28nm FD-SOI |7nm FinFET |- |Implementations | | |[[Tesla Autopilot]] Hardware 1 Model S & X (09-'14 - 10-'16) | | |} ==Competition== Mobileye faces competition from Tier 1 automotive suppliers as well as from other technology companies, including potentially Google.[https://web.archive.org/web/20140806114832/http://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1607310/000157104914003550/t1401453-424b4.htm] There is also an increasing competition on the after-market space from radar-based systems manufacturers, such as Safe Drive Systems and others.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.fenderbender.com/FenderBender/March-2014/Safe-Drive-Systems-Launches-Anti-Collision-Technology-in-US/ |title=Safe Drive Systems Launches Anti-Collision Technology in U.S. | March 06, 2014 |publisher=FenderBender |date=2014-03-06 |accessdate=2017-03-18}} Other competitors developing ADAS technology include [https://www.seeingmachines.com/ Seeing Machines], [[Cognitive Technologies]], [[Continental AG]],{{cite web|url=http://www.conti-online.com/www/automotive_de_en/themes/passenger_cars/chassis_safety/adas/ |title=Continental Automotive -Advanced Driver Assistance Systems |website=Conti-online.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.conti-online.com/www/automotive_de_en/themes/commercial_vehicles/chassis_safety/adas/ |title=Continental Automotive -Advanced Driver Assistance Systems |website=Conti-online.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-18}} [[Robert Bosch GmbH|Bosch]],[https://web.archive.org/web/20141031172512/http://www.bosch-mobility-solutions.com/en/de/driving_safety/driving_safety_systems_for_passenger_cars_1/driver_assistance_systems/driver_assistance_systems_2.html ][https://web.archive.org/web/20141113065846/http://www.bosch-mobility-solutions.com/en/de/driving_comfort/driving_comfort_systems_for_passenger_cars_1/driver_assistance_systems_4/driver_assistance_systems_5.html ] [[NVIDIA]],{{cite web|url=http://www.nvidia.com/object/advanced-driver-assistance-systems.html |title=Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS) | NVIDIA DRIVE |publisher=NVIDIA |date= |accessdate=2017-03-18}} [[OmniVision Technologies]],{{cite web|url=http://www.ovt.com/applications/application.php?id=7 |title=Overview | Automotive Imaging | OmniVision |website=Ovt.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-18}} [[Freescale]],{{cite web|url=http://www.freescale.com/webapp/sps/site/overview.jsp?code=ADAS&tid=vanADAS |title=NXP Semiconductors | Automotive, Security, IoT |website=Freescale.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-18}} [[Texas Instruments]],{{cite web|url=http://www.ti.com/lsds/ti/apps/automotive/adas/overview.page |title=Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS) Solutions | Overview |website=TI.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-18}}{{cite web|url=http://am.renesas.com/applications/automotive/adas/index.jsp |title=Advanced Driver Assistance System (ADAS) | Renesas Electronics America |website=Am.renesas.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-18}} [[Toshiba]],{{cite web|url=http://asia.nikkei.com/Business/Companies/Toshiba-to-supply-chips-for-driver-assist-systems |title=Toshiba to supply chips for driver-assist systems- Nikkei Asian Review
